conclusion: Use Snell's Law and geometry to find the refractive index.
The glass column has a radius R and a quarter circle cross-section.
The distance from point P to the AC interface is sqrt(3)R/2 and MC = sqrt(3)R/3.
Point P is located at an angle theta from the vertical line AC.
Using trigonometry, sin(theta) = sqrt(3)/2, so theta = 60 degrees or pi/3 radians.
Point M is vertically above C by sqrt(3)R/3.
Snell's Law: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2).
n1 is the refractive index of air (approximately 1), and n2 is the refractive index of the glass.
Light enters the glass at theta1 = 60 degrees and exits at theta2.
The horizontal distance from P to M is R(1 - sqrt(3)/3).
Use Snell's Law: 1 * sin(60 degrees) = n2 * sin(theta2).
Solve for n2 using the calculated theta2.
The refractive index n2 of the glass column is approximately sqrt(3).
The refractive index of the glass column is sqrt(3).
